description: From Middle English clam (“viscous, sticky; slimy”)  +‎ -y, from Old English clǣman (“to smear, bedaub”). Compare German klamm (“clammy”) and klemmen (“to be stuck, stick”). See also clam.

entries.meaning: Cold and damp, usually referring to hands or palms.
examples: His hands were clammy from fright.

entries.meaning: (medicine) The quality of normal skin signs, epidermis that is neither diaphoretic nor dry.
